Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
Unbiased Determination of Genome Wide Mutations Rates in Single Bacterial Replication Events

From Darwin's theory of natural selection to Mendelian inheritance and variation, many theories have preceded experimental evidence explaining evolution and population genetics. Specifically, the relationship between mutation rate and its effect on a strain?s fitness in a population of competing strains remains elusive, despite it being absolutely essential for understanding the mechanism of evolution and speciation. Current methods that assay mutations suffer from outputting information free of clonal interference, and insufficient resolution to probe rare single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) that occur in the single-cell level. Thus, these approaches are not neutral, and select against deleterious mutations. An innovative cell sorting and culture microfluidic system will deliver unbiased genome wide microbial mutation rates that include neutral, synonymous, and deleterious mutations. Using this technology, the relationship between fitness and genome wide mutation rates can be directly examined.

The Fellow will receive interdisciplinary training in the physics and engineering of microfluidics (Dr. Paul Blainey), biology, and informatics (Dr. Eric Alm). All data will be open to use for development of educational material and for aiding phylogenic reconstruction. Additionally, an automated DNA sequencing library preparation device design and operational knowledge will be made public for reduced library preparation cost for the entire sequencing community. The Fellow will also mentor undergraduate students to teach the power of bringing engineering approaches to answer basic science questions in evolutionary biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Next generation sequencing (NGS) has revolutionized the study of biology. The accessibility and low cost of reading nucleic acid sequences has transformed our understanding of biology. However, while the cost to sequence large whole genomes has been dropping, sequencing many samples remains challenging due to the primitive state of whole genome sequencing sample preparation (SP) methods. Current studies that are limited by the SP throughput include clinical resequencing of viral and pathogen genomes for the antibiotic resistance surveillance isolate sequencing and metagenomic sequencing of environmental samples to track ecological changes, and time resolved single-cell genomics. During the fellowship period, we developed an integrated cell sorting, culturing, and whole genome sequencing SP system based on optical trapping and microfluidics. The microfluidic device integrates the entire SP process — from cell lysis to barcoding — allowing SP cost to lower by two orders of magnitude by reducing reagent consumption and full automation. With this technology, we can also sort single bacteria cells without distinctive markers or phenotypes; for example, sort two identical daughter cells from each other.

The microfluidic device is a dual-layered polydimethysiloxane block, engraved with fluid circuitry necessary for the entire SP processes for NGS. The circuitry design consists of 96-plexed, 36-nanoliter reactors and filter valves that mixes reagents and perform bead-based molecular selection in parallel. Reagents for NGS SP are precisely metered into reactors and mixed for cell lysis, DNA fragmentation, and adapter tagging. Subsequently, the processed DNA fragments are purified by mixing in SPRI beads, then washing and eluting with novel filter valves that selectively retain beads while letting fluid through. With the device, 96 bacteria cell samples can be processed into sequence ready libraries with 15% conversion efficiency. The device libraries performed equally against conventionally prepared libraries in variant calling accuracy, fragment size distribution, and unique k-mer abundance.

With our system, we performed two studies that were difficult to conduct using conventional SP methodologies due to cost; we 1) investigated the evolution of pathogens in the human lung by whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing clinical isolates of Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PA) and 2) evaluated the error modes of variant calling in whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing by creating triplicate libraries for every sample then adjusting variant calling filters to achieve high sensitivity and specificity.The diversity of pathogens has been measured in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) as it needs immediate attention. The symptoms of CF make the lung a habitable environment for pathogens to persist, thus giving them the opportunity to evolve and diversity over long periods of time. Unsurprisingly, the results show that PA in CF patients are diverse in both latitudinal and longitudinal studies. However, bacterial diversity in non-CF humans remains elusive because the SP cost limits such a study from being prioritized. Utilizing our low cost microfluidic SP technology, we processed 124 clinical isolates of PA from six patients, not known to have CF from the Brigham Women’s Hospital (Boston, USA), into sequencing libraries. In concordance with other reports, the genomes of inter-patient subject samples were vastly diverse in their gene content and had on average 50,000 SNPs from each other. However, the intra-subject PA isolates were completely clonal with only two of the six subjects having SNPs (less than two SNP sites) between 24 intra-subject isolates. Our results suggest that environments with high selection forces, such as the lung, can suppress evolutionary forces to drive bacteria to a single lineage.
